metadata.title: What is the radical content problem, and does your recommender system suffer from it? | by Ville Kuosmanen | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: What is the radical content problem, and does your recommender system suffer from it?

all_paragraphs: This post is part 3 in my series of posts about explainable recommendations, based on my BSc dissertation. Part 1 introduces the concept of explainable recommendations, while part 2 covers my implementation of explainable movie recommendations using Python and React.js.

Recommender systems have seen increased usage over the past decade, and they’re considered an integral part of applications such as YouTube, Netflix and Amazon. While recommendations have helped users find the videos, movies, or items they like in a limitless ocean of options, they’ve not done so without problems. Recently some recommender systems have faced criticism for directing users to a “rabbit hole” of increasingly radical content. An example of such system is YouTube’s recommendation system, which recommends videos and channels for a user based on their watch history. When studying right-wing channels, researchers found some evidence that YouTube’s recommendations algorithm radicalised users by recommending increasingly radical channels to them [1]. It’s worth noting that this doesn’t mean there’s anything wrong with the recommender system — in fact, it seems to work exactly as it was designed to, recommending videos accurately to users who would be interested in watching them. This problem can be called the radical content problem, and little academic research has been conducted on solving it.

As an extension to my dissertation on explainable recommendations, I chose to seek out whether any of the explainability approaches could be used in discouraging the recommendation systems from recommending increasingly radical content, or discovering if the problem exists in the first place. Explainability in recommender systems has previously been mainly concerned with user experience, but perhaps it could help data scientists understand their own models better as well?

Recommender systems based on latent factor models are highly uninterpretable. So far post-hoc explanation methods such as association rules [2] have been used in explaining individual recommendations. However, since the set of association rules encapsulates the recommender system’s behaviour as a whole, it could be used to discover knowledge about the recommender system as a whole. To do that, the recommender system was mapped as a network using the generated association rules. Since the association rules are of form (X, Z => Y), they can be considered a directed graph where X, Z and Y are nodes of the graph. This graph can then be visualised using standard graph visualisation techniques. The figure below shows a generated graph using the association rules mined from the MovieLens 20m dataset. Note that rules of type (X, Y) => Z are shown in two edges, X => Z and Y => Z.

The visualised graph can potentially be used to answer many questions about the underlying recommender system, but the most interesting one is whether the system suffers from the extreme content problem, referring to a recommender system that recommends more and more extreme, niche items to users who have rated popular, mild items. This problem is of particular interest to open video platforms like YouTube, which has been accused of promoting more extreme content to viewers of popular, milder “gateway” videos [1]. To analyse the network quantitatively, a proper metric for “extremeness” should be defined. An example of an extremeness score for movies could be its classified age rating. Content in platforms that have no objective age ratings, such as YouTube and Twitter, would likely be far harder to rank in extremeness, but machine learning techniques such as sentiment analysis could possibly be used for this.

Every item could then be assigned an extremeness score, and parts of the network where extremeness increases as one moves closer to the centre of a cluster could be identified automatically. Because extreme content tends to focus on particular communities or groups of users, the analysis should be done on cluster-based association rules rather than ones mined globally (as is done here). This would potentially allow the platform administrators to easily and objectively find the most radical communities, and set appropriate restrictions or age ratings to their content if needed.

In this case, visual inspection of the network seems to place films such as The Shawshank Redemption, The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers and The Godfather to the centre of the network, which seem to be no more extremist than their antecedents. As such, visual inspection of the network suggests that the recommender system described here does not suffer from the extreme content problem. Of course, a more thorough analytical inspection should be conducted to confirm the finding, but this was out of scope for this project.

This post concludes my series on explainable recommender systems. I enjoyed learning more about the need and challenges of explainable artificial intelligence, as well as gaining a deep understanding of recommender systems in the process. Thanks for reading!

[2]: Peake, G., & Wang, J. (2018, July). Explanation mining: Post hoc interpretability of latent factor models for recommendation systems. In Proceedings of the 24th ACM SIGKDD International Conference on Knowledge Discovery & Data Mining (pp. 2060–2069). ACM.
